title: The 41-page ‘blueprint’ that shines a light on Trump chaos
text:
One of Trump’s top economic advisers has written a 41-page document that lays out the possibility of achieving just such an agreement, through a combination of tariffs and other policies. Now, foreign bankers, Wall Street traders and congressional aides alike are reading it in search of clues. Written by Stephen Miran, chair of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, “A User’s Guide to Restructuring the Global Trading System” has emerged as what many observers hope is a blueprint for trying to understand the administration’s erratic economic policy.

Roughly 80 years later, President Donald Trump’s chaotic trade policies have fuelled speculation among investors and economists that a modern-day equivalent may be on the horizon - a “Mar-a-Lago accord” to revise those postwar global trade rules, crafted at his resort in Palm Beach, Florida.

In July 1944, during World War II, hundreds of economic policymakers from dozens of countries gathered at a hotel in Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, to establish a new framework for the global financial system once the war ended. The resulting Bretton Woods agreement has shaped international trade ever since.

Miran’s paper argues that unilateral tariffs may be necessary to force US trading partners to make changes. He writes that the dollar’s strength for the past half-century has made US exports too expensive for the rest of the world to buy, and imports too cheap for US consumers to pass up, degrading US manufacturing and industrial output. Trump, Miran suggests, could try to force scores of countries to increase the value of their currencies – possibly through a US-launched trade war that puts unrelenting economic pressure on the rest of the world. (Miran describes the idea only as one of a handful of options, rather than a definitive set of recommendations.)

Loading

For now, there is no indication the White House is moving forward with a Mar-a-Lago accord. Trump has discussed his upcoming set of tariffs as aimed at getting other countries to lower their own import taxes, and Miran said in an interview that a global currency agreement is not what the administration is pursuing. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has said publicly that he thinks the US dollar should be strong, whereas the ideas Miran outlines would require the dollar to be weaker than other countries’ currencies.

“The president’s very clear on fair and reciprocal tariffs,” Miran told The Washington Post. “Anyone thinking what I wrote in November is the policy agenda we’re secretly implementing right now is just looking for something to write about.”

And yet the paper has attracted a great deal of interest from economists and other observers at home and abroad who are trying to understand the pain inflicted by the tariffs as part of a broader vision. Some Wall Street analysts have pointed out that even if Trump’s aides are not moving forward with a Mar-a-Lago accord now, the administration could seek a currency agreement later. Trump’s goal to revive domestic manufacturing might be impossible just by having other countries lower their tariffs on US exports, raising the possibility that Miran’s broader program reemerges down the line. And while there are no signs of a global currency agreement, Trump’s aides are saying publicly that they are targeting countries they think have artificially devalued their currencies – reflecting one of the core ideas in Miran’s paper.

title: Kangaroos or Wallabies? Fans face choice in rival clashes with England
text:
League or Union? Kangaroos or Wallabies? Liverpool or Twickenham?

Rugby lovers are set to be handed an unprecedented “decisions, decisions” moment when Australia face England in two mouth-watering Ashes duels in the different codes 275km apart at the very same time this November.

The confirmation of the Kangaroos itinerary to England in October and November in the first three-Test rugby league ‘Ashes’ series since 2003 has brought delight in both countries that one of the great rivalries in world sport is being rekindled after 22 years.

But there’ll be disappointment that the second of the three Tests will be played at Everton’s new soccer stadium at the same time the Wallabies are duelling England at Twickenham in a fixture given fresh impetus last year when Australia won one of the greatest matches between the old foes.

title: The $9m man: Aussie reality star wins one of biggest prizes in TV history
text:
Former Australian Survivor winner David Genat, nicknamed “The Golden God”, has just bagged himself a lot more gold. The ex-model who lives in Perth has won the second season of US series Deal or No Deal Island, taking home $US5.8 million ($A9.2 million).

It’s one of the biggest cash prizes in TV history – second only to the winner of Amazon Prime’s Beast Games, who received a whopping $US10 million ($A15.9 million) last month.

David Genat and Joe Manganiello in the season finale of Deal or No Deal Island. Credit: Monty Brinton/NBC

“I want to be clear, if you take this offer, this would be the most money anyone’s ever made on network television,” said host Joe Manganiello, as Genat deliberated between his final two cases containing $US75 and $US12,232,001. “You would truly be The Golden God.”

“But if you turn this down, and you have $75 in your case, David, you would be the biggest loser in TV history.” The deal was offered by Chrissy Teigen, who was unveiled as the mysterious “banker” in the final episode – two decades after appearing as a briefcase model on the first season of the original show.

title: Abusing your team is one thing. But filming it? You’re the embarrassment
text:
The international break is over, and the Premier League is about to return — and that means the latest episode of The People vs. Ange Postecoglou is set to drop imminently.

In the last episode, we saw the eponymous hero/villain respond to another mouthy fan who was fuming about Tottenham Hotspur’s latest defeat to Fulham. Or he was a Fulham fan gloating; we don’t know for sure.

“Ange! What the f--- was that!?” he asked Postecoglou, repeatedly. “What was that!?”

Postecoglou stopped and confronted him. “Behave yourself,” he replied. “You’re a young man, just learn some manners. Behave yourself.”

title: Residents push back against 'dumb' bin announcement as Australians adopt major change
text:
FOGO bins have had a mixed response in many parts of Australia, but environmentalists say it's the only way to tackle our landfill crisis quietly playing out.

All households in Perth will have FOGO bins by the end of this year. Source: Supplied/CityofPortPhillip

FOGO bins have become a widely debated waste management strategy, with councils across Australia adopting them to ease pressure on landfill. But despite pushback from some residents, environmentalists argue their benefits far outweigh the drawbacks.

Now implemented in dozens of local government areas nationwide, Perth is set to roll out FOGO bins to every household by the end of the year. In some regions, this shift has led to red-lidded general waste bins being collected fortnightly instead of weekly — a change that has sparked concern among residents, particularly those in larger households, over potential odours from accumulating waste.

Concern bubbled up this week when the City of Rockingham announced plans to move to fortnightly red bin collections in June, prompting pushback from some community members worried about hygiene and practicality.

Meanwhile, Kwinana’s new three-bin system, set to launch in late April, which will introduce a green-lid bin for organic waste such as grass clippings and weeds. However, this change comes with a caveat — a significantly smaller red bin for general waste.

Some resident will need to make do with a smaller general waste bin. Source: Supplied/NCA

Perth locals question new bin pick-up strategy

Long-term Rockingham resident Thomas Soderholm said changing the bin collection timetable was a "dumb" cost-cutting measure. He said in a household of seven with a two-year-old who was still in nappies, leaving the bins out was "going to stink".

ADVERTISEMENT

"Imagine if you have a crayfish party? In this case, it’s nappies galore," he told The West Australian.

The impending changes has already received pushback from residents, who have set up petitions to fight the changes, one of which has already attracted more than 4,400 signatures.

A motion to review the FOGO policy was shelved by Rockingham councillors in a meeting in March last year, where residents’ concerns were raised. Earlier this month, Kwinana Mayor Peter Feasey announced the introduction of its three-bin system including the lime green GO (garden organics) bin.

"The introduction of the GO bin will make waste management smarter, cleaner, and more environmentally friendly, as well as promoting sustainable waste management practices in our community,” he said in a statement.

ADVERTISEMENT

He explained "a range of factors" were considered to "determine the appetite" for a third bin, ranging from economic and environmental to social and governance. "An average of 34 per cent of Kwinana’s current general waste bin is filled with compostable garden organics," he said.

City of Kwinana Mayor, Peter Feasey using the new GO bin. Source: Supplied

"By separating garden waste, we can turn it into valuable compost, supporting a greener Kwinana."

However, residents shared their distaste for the new system on a recent Facebook post from the council, arguing the move was a "waste of money" that “doesn’t seem logical".

Why are FOGO bins controversial and what do they do for the environment?

FOGO bins have sparked controversy in many parts of Australia in recent times. The bins, designed to collect food scraps and garden waste for composting, aim to reduce landfill waste and cut greenhouse gas emissions.

ADVERTISEMENT

However, their implementation has been met with resistance due to concerns over odours, additional sorting efforts and potential costs for households. Some residents argue that the process is inconvenient, especially in warmer climates where decomposing food waste can create strong smells if not managed properly. Others worry about potential rate increases to fund collection and processing.

Despite these concerns, supporters say FOGO bins offer clear environmental benefits. Food waste is a major contributor to landfill, where it produces methane — a potent greenhouse gas. By diverting organic waste to composting facilities, FOGO bins significantly reduce emissions while creating nutrient-rich compost that can improve soil health and support agriculture.

Many councils that have adopted FOGO systems have reported reduced landfill costs and higher overall recycling rates. Additionally, when properly managed, odour issues can be minimised through the use of compostable liners and regular emptying.

While some Australians remain skeptical, the bins' long-term environmental impact is clear. As landfill space becomes increasingly limited and climate concerns grow, transitioning to more sustainable waste management practices is a necessary step, experts say.

with NCA Newswire

title: Coles shoppers unleash over 'frantic' checkout demand: 'Meant to stop theft'
text:
Customers are being told to void their transactions and start again if they didn't bag bulky items first. But so far, no explanation has been offered as to why.

Customers say Coles staff are making them start the bagging process again if they fail to scan bulky items first. Source: Getty/Yahoo News Australia

In what appears to be a system increasing in prevalence at Coles supermarkets around the country, customers are again hitting out at what they say is a "dumb" self-checkout rule which requires shoppers to scan bulky items first.

Numerous reports of the apparent policy first started emerging online last year, with Australians questioning why Coles staff told them to scan large items — such as boxed goods, value packs or bottled water — before everything else.

In many instances, shoppers said "frantic" employees even "insisted" they "void" their transactions to start again if they hadn't begun with bulky products, even if they were already well into the bagging process. Yahoo News has questioned Coles on multiple occasions about the alleged system, which is not communicated either in-store or online.

In the months since these cases starting emerging, so far there's been no detailed explanation. Coles told Yahoo its staff are encouraged to help shoppers process and scan bulky items first to reduce theft, but it didn't explain whether it's a proven, evidence-based approach. This week, another post on the matter attracted over 2,000 responses.

Coles has again attracted attention over a policy apparently enforced by staff that requires shoppers scan bulky items before everything else. Source: ABC/Facebook

Coles shoppers hit out over secretive anti-theft measure

Those replying were largely fed-up customers. "I was buying a few bits and pieces at Coles, including a 10-pack of canned water," it read. "At the self-checkout, I scanned the smaller items first while I cradled the water and one of the helpers came to me a bit panicky.

ADVERTISEMENT

"She asked if she could void the transaction so the waters would scan first. I said 'it's OK, it's already scanned' and I was ready to pay, but she pleaded with me to let her, or she'd get in trouble. I was a bit confused, but she seemed genuinely worried, so I let her. Can anyone explain why she needed to make sure the waters were scanned first?"

Do you work at Coles and have been asked to enforce this? Or has this happened to you as a shopper? Email Joe Attanasio at joe.attanasio@yahooinc.com

Over 700 people wrote back, a significant portion revealing a similar experience. "That explains the frantic worker yesterday. WTF," one person said. "I noticed this too with bulky items. I imagine it's so you don't leave it in your cart and 'forget' to scan them," said another.

The supermarket earlier issued an apology to customers who had been told to void their transactions and start again. On Wednesday, Yahoo News questioned Coles again, asking to clarify the reasoning behind the policy.

Coles responds to self-serve policy

We asked when it was introduced and why it has not been publicly communicated to customers. In response, it claimed customers actually appreciate being assisted with their bulky items.

ADVERTISEMENT

"We know that helping our customers with bulky or heavy items can be a big help — this is all about providing great service", a spokesperson said. "The focus on having our team members scan the bulkier items first also helps to avoid situations where bulkier items are accidentally left in the trolley and not scanned.

"However, we certainly don’t want our team members to ‘void’ a customer's shopping simply to have bulk items like toilet paper scanned first. In the isolated cases where this is happening, we would encourage our customers to provide us with this feedback directly, so we can provide coaching and prevent this."

While it's certainly no secret that shoplifting is a major issue across Australia's supermarkets and retailers, with both Coles and Woolworths implementing a raft of recent measures to combat the problem, there doesn't appear to be any specific evidence or research that suggests scanning bulkier items first reduces instances of theft.

"It's 'meant' to stop theft of large items. It doesn't. But there are KPI's and reports that flag a self-serve attendant if they don't get scanned first," a person commented.

ADVERTISEMENT

"I’ve had them demand I do the bulky ones first, like toilet paper. I want to do it last because it’s light and the heavy things can go first," another person chimed in. "The assistant rudely came up and pulled it out of my trolley to try to scan it at the self-checkout and argued with me about it."

"They always ask me if I want them to put the water through first, I just say no," another said.

A person claiming to be a Coles employee urged the public not to take the policy out on floor staff.

"Please don't take it out on the staff at stores, this is a push by the upper levels to reduce theft. If you have a complaint about it, flood the customer care line or better yet, publicly do it on their Facebook and social media accounts."

ADVERTISEMENT

"Yes, the self-serve person — trying to manage 10 checkouts by themselves — will actually get in trouble if they don't get everyone to put the bulky items first," another apparent staffer said.

Do you have a story tip? Email: newsroomau@yahoonews.com.
